title: Biamanga National Park
text:
Biamanga National Park is a <a href="protected%20area">protected area</a> in <a href="New%20South%20Wales">New South Wales</a>, Australia, south of <a href="Sydney">Sydney</a> and north of <a href="Bega%2C%20New%20South%20Wales">Bega</a>. The park forms part of the <a href="Ulladulla%20to%20Merimbula%20Important%20Bird%20Area">Ulladulla to Merimbula Important Bird Area</a> because of its importance for <a href="swift%20parrot">swift parrot</a>s.
Its name derives from Yuin elder <a href="Biamanga%20%28person%29">Biamanga</a>, aka "King Jack Mumbulla", after whom Mumbulla Mountain was also named. It is an important <a href="Aboriginal%20Australian">Aboriginal</a> site for the <a href="Yuin%20people">Yuin people</a> and a prominent landmark that can be seen from across the <a href="Bega%20Valley">Bega Valley</a>, also known as Biamanga. Proclaimed in 1994 and extended in 1997, the park covers . It is seen by the <a href="traditional%20owners">traditional owners</a> as "part of a single cultural landscape" with the <a href="Gulaga%20National%20Park">Gulaga National Park</a>, and also has cultural links to <a href="Merriman%20Island">Umbarra</a> (Merriman Island), <a href="Barunguba">Barunguba</a> (Montague Island), and <a href="Dithol">Dithol</a> (Pigeon House Mountain).
In November 2021 Mumballa Mountain was ascribed the <a href="dual%20name">dual name</a> of Biamanga.
Geology.
The mountain is the remnants an ancient <a href="shield%20volcano">shield volcano</a>, and <a href="granite">granite</a> rock formations and <a href="boulder">boulder</a>s are visible along the course of Mumbulla Creek.
History.
The park lies in the lands of one of the <a href="Yuin">Yuin</a> peoples, who have inhabited the area for thousands of years.
20th century.
Extensive <a href="logging">logging</a> was taking place in the area up until the 1970s, and in 1967 some of the rock was blasted with dynamite in the interests of improving television reception, and a television transmitter tower for <a href="WIN-4">WIN-4</a> was built on the mountain. After concerns had been raised by local people, the NSW Government set up an advisory committee in 1977 to investigate the <a href="woodchipping">woodchipping</a> industry and in the same year 1977 <a href="Guboo%20Ted%20Thomas">Guboo Ted Thomas</a>, a Yuin <a href="Aboriginal%20elder">elder</a>, led a protest against the destruction of the forest on Mumbulla Mountain. On 15 July 1980, the <a href="New%20South%20Wales%20Government">New South Wales Government</a> declared an area of around an "<a href="Aboriginal%20place">Aboriginal place</a>" and a "Protected Archaeological Area" under the "<a href="National%20Parks%20and%20Wildlife%20Act%201974">National Parks and Wildlife Act 1974</a>" (NSW).
The park was proclaimed in 1994 and extended in 1997.
21st century.
Further protests against logging activities took place in 2010.
On 30 November 2021 Mumballa Mountain was ascribed the <a href="dual%20name">dual name</a> of Biamanga.
Description.
The park covers . It is seen by the <a href="traditional%20owners">traditional owners</a> as "part of a single cultural landscape" with the Gulaga National Park.
Flora and fauna.
There are <a href="monkey%20gum">monkey gum</a>s and <a href="ribbon%20gum">ribbon gum</a> along the creeks, and the park is home to <a href="chef%27s%20cap%20correa">chef's cap correa</a>, an <a href="endangered%20species">endangered species</a>.
The park forms part of the <a href="Ulladulla%20to%20Merimbula%20Important%20Bird%20Area">Ulladulla to Merimbula Important Bird Area</a>, identified as such by <a href="BirdLife%20International">BirdLife International</a> because of its importance for <a href="swift%20parrot">swift parrot</a>s. <a href="Azure%20kingfisher">Azure kingfisher</a>s and <a href="superb%20fairywren">superb fairywren</a>s abound in the park.
Management.
Biamanga has been jointly managed by the traditional owners and the <a href="National%20Parks%20and%20Wildlife%20Service%20%28New%20South%20Wales%29">National Parks and Wildlife Service</a> NSW since 2006. The traditional custodians are represented by two <a href="Local%20Aboriginal%20Land%20Council">Local Aboriginal Land Council</a>s, the Merrimans and Bega LALCs, which own the title to the land and lease it back to the <a href="New%20South%20Wales%20Government">New South Wales Government</a> for use as a <a href="national%20park">national park</a>.
Aboriginal significance and sites.
The mountain and surrounds have important cultural links to <a href="Merriman%20Island">Umbarra</a> (Merriman Island), <a href="Barunguba">Barunguba</a> (Montague Island), and <a href="Dithol">Dithol</a> (Pigeon House Mountain). The mountain is of particular significance to the people of <a href="Wallaga%20Lake">Wallaga Lake</a>.
The park contains important Aboriginal sites, in particular Biamanga, also known as Mumbulla Mountain, which is part a large <a href="Aboriginal%20ceremony">ceremonial</a> and cultural track on the <a href="South%20Coast%20%28New%20South%20Wales%29">South Coast of New South Wales</a> that includes other <a href="Aboriginal%20sacred%20site">Aboriginal sacred site</a>s of particular importance to the <a href="Yuin">Yuin</a> peoples. The mountain was named after Yuin leader <a href="King%20Jack%20Mumbulla">King Jack Mumbulla</a>, aka Jack Mumbler, whose "tribal" name was Biamanga. King Jack would spend time communing with the ancestor spirits on the highest peak of the mountain and send <a href="smoke%20signal">smoke signal</a>s for his people to see. <a href="Initiation%20ceremonies">Initiation ceremonies</a> were held by Yuin people at various spots on the mountain, with the last recorded one held there in 1918. It has been described as a "men's law mountain".
Independent evidence of the sacredness of the site was provided in 1964 by linguist <a href="Luise%20Hercus">Luise Hercus</a> and by musician and linguist <a href="Janet%20Mathews">Janet Mathews</a>, but only made publicly available in the late 1970s; as well as by notes made much earlier by <a href="Alfred%20William%20Howitt">Alfred William Howitt</a>, an ethnologist who attended a Yuin initiation ceremony in 1883.
The Biamanga protest site is of additional significance both to Yuin and to all other <a href="Indigenous%20Australians">Indigenous Australians</a>, "as a representation of embodying the <a href="Indigenous%20land%20rights%20in%20Australia">Australian Aboriginal campaign for land rights</a> and <a href="Aboriginal%20self-determination">Aboriginal self-determination</a>.
